Chloe Anthony Wofford Morrison (born Chloe Ardelia Wofford; February 18, 1931 – August 5, 2019), known as Toni Morrison, was an American novelist.
Born and raised in Lorain, Ohio, Morrison graduated from Howard University in 1953 with a B.A. in English.
Morrison became the first black female editor in fiction at Random House in New York City in the late 1960s.
Morrison's works are praised for addressing the harsh consequences of racism in the United States.
She was honored with the National Book Foundation's Medal of Distinguished Contribution to American Letters the same year.
She received the PEN/Saul Bellow Award for Achievement in American Fiction in 2016.
Chloe Ardelia Wofford, the second of four children from a working-class, black family, was born in Lorain, Ohio, to Ramah (née Willis) and George Wofford.
Her mother was born in Greenville, Alabama, and moved north with her family as a child.
George Wofford grew up in Cartersville, Georgia.
Soon after the lynching, George Wofford moved to the racially integrated town of Lorain, Ohio, in the hope of escaping racism and securing gainful employment in Ohio's burgeoning industrial economy.
Soon after the lynching, George Wofford moved to the racially integrated town of Lorain, Ohio, in the hope of escaping racism and securing gainful employment in Ohio's burgeoning industrial economy.
He worked odd jobs and as a welder for U.S. Steel.
She became a Catholic at the age of 12 and took the baptismal name Anthony (after Anthony of Padua), which led to her nickname, Toni.
In 1949, she enrolled at Howard University in Washington, D.C., seeking the company of fellow black intellectuals.
Her master's thesis was titled "Virginia Woolf's and William Faulkner's treatment of the alienated."
She taught English, first at Texas Southern University in Houston from 1955 to 1957, and then at Howard University for the next seven years.
After her divorce and the birth of her son Slade in 1965, Morrison began working as an editor for L. W. Singer, a textbook division of publisher Random House, in Syracuse, New York.
Two years later, she transferred to Random House in New York City, where she became their first black woman senior editor in the fiction department.

Among other books that Morrison developed and edited is The Black Book (1974), an anthology of photographs, illustrations, essays, and documents of black life in the United States from the time of slavery to the 1920s.

Alvin Beam reviewed the anthology for the Cleveland Plain Dealer, writing: "Editors, like novelists, have brain children – books they think up and bring to life without putting their own names on the title page.
The novel did not sell well at first, but the City University of New York put The Bluest Eye on its reading list for its new Black studies department, as did other colleges, which boosted sales.
Her third novel, Song of Solomon (1977), follows the life of Macon "Milkman" Dead III, from birth to adulthood, as he discovers his heritage.
In 1983, Morrison left publishing to devote more time to writing, while living in a converted boathouse on the Hudson River in Nyack, New York.
In 1983, Morrison left publishing to devote more time to writing, while living in a converted boathouse on the Hudson River in Nyack, New York.
She taught English at two branches of the State University of New York (SUNY) and at Rutgers University's New Brunswick campus.
In 1984, she was appointed to an Albert Schweitzer chair at the University at Albany, SUNY.
The play was performed in 1986 at the State University of New York at Albany, where she was teaching at the time.

sentence: In 2019, Timothy Greenfield-Sanders' documentary Toni Morrison: The Pieces I Am premiered at the Sundance Film Festival.
She earned a master's degree in American Literature from Cornell University in 1955.
After her divorce and the birth of her son Slade in 1965, Morrison began working as an editor for L. W. Singer, a textbook division of publisher Random House, in Syracuse, New York.

That year she also published her first book of literary criticism, Playing in the Dark: Whiteness and the Literary Imagination (1992), an examination of the African-American presence in white American literature.
section: == Career == | === The Beloved Trilogy and the Nobel Prize: 1987–1998 ===

sentence: Morrison returned to Margaret Garner's life story, the basis of her novel Beloved, to write the libretto for a new opera, Margaret Garner.
Morrison returned to Margaret Garner's life story, the basis of her novel Beloved, to write the libretto for a new opera, Margaret Garner.

In 2004, she put together a children's book called Remember to mark the 50th anniversary of the Brown v. Board of Education Supreme Court decision in 1954 that declared racially segregated public schools to be unconstitutional.

This triumph is commensurate with its ambition, since it was Morrison's intention in writing it precisely to expand the range of classic American literature, to enter, as a living black woman, the company of dead white males like Faulkner, Melville, Hawthorne and Twain.
Morrison's eleventh novel, God Help the Child, was published in 2015.
Her second son Slade Kevin was born after her divorce, in 1965.
Morrison was not afraid to comment on American politics and race relations.
